Indications and doses

Vulvovaginal candidiasis,

By mouth

  • For adults
    200 mg twice daily for 1 day.

Vulvovaginal candidiasis (recurrent),

By mouth

  • For adults
    50–100 mg daily for 6 months.

Oral or oesophageal candidiasis that has not responded to fluconazole,

By mouth using oral solution

  • For adults
    100–200 mg twice daily for 2 weeks (continue for another 2 weeks if no response; the higher dose should not be used for longer than 2 weeks if no signs of improvement).

Oral or oesophageal candidiasis in HIV-positive or other immunocompromised patients,

By mouth using oral solution

  • For adults
    200 mg daily in 1–2 divided doses for 1 week (continue for another week if no response).

Systemic candidiasis where other antifungal drugs inappropriate or ineffective,

By intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    100–200 mg once daily.
  • For adults
    200 mg every 12 hours for 2 days, then 200 mg once daily for max. 12 days.

Pityriasis versicolor,

By mouth

  • For adults
    200 mg once daily for 7 days.

Tinea pedis, Tinea manuum,

By mouth

  • For adults
    100 mg once daily for 30 days, alternatively 200 mg twice daily for 7 days.

Tinea corporis, Tinea cruris,

By mouth

  • For adults
    100 mg once daily for 15 days, alternatively 200 mg once daily for 7 days.

Onychomycosis,

By mouth

  • For adults
    200 mg once daily for 3 months, alternatively 200 mg twice daily for 7 days, subsequent courses repeated after 21-day intervals; fingernails 2 courses, toenails 3 courses.

Aspergillosis,

By mouth

  • For adults
    200 mg twice daily.

Systemic aspergillosis where other antifungal drugs inappropriate or ineffective,

By intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    200 mg every 12 hours for 2 days, then 200 mg once daily for max. 12 days.

Histoplasmosis,

By intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    200 mg 3 times a day for 3 days, then 200 mg 1–2 times a day.
  • For adults
    200 mg every 12 hours for 2 days, then 200 mg once daily for max. 12 days.

Systemic cryptococcosis including cryptococcal meningitis where other antifungal drugs inappropriate or ineffective,

By intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    200 mg once daily, dose increased in invasive or disseminated disease and in cryptococcal meningitis, increased to 200 mg twice daily.
  • For adults
    200 mg every 12 hours for 2 days, then 200 mg once daily for max. 12 days.

Maintenance in HIV-infected patients to prevent relapse of underlying fungal infection and prophylaxis in neutropenia when standard therapy inappropriate,

By mouth

  • For adults
    200 mg once daily, then increased to 200 mg twice daily, dose increased only if low plasma-itraconazole concentration.

Prophylaxis of deep fungal infections (when standard therapy inappropriate) in patients with haematological malignancy or undergoing bone-marrow transplantation who are expected to become neutropenic,

By mouth using oral solution

  • For adults
    5 mg/kg daily in 2 divided doses, to be started before transplantation or before chemotherapy (taking care to avoid interaction with cytotoxic drugs) and continued until neutrophil count recovers, safety and efficacy not established in elderly patients.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Manufacturer advises use only in life-threatening situations (toxicity at high doses in animal studies).

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Dose reduction may be necessary.

Use only if potential benefit outweighs risk of hepatotoxicity.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Risk of congestive heart failure.

With oral use

Bioavailability of oral formulations possibly reduced.

With intravenous use

Use intravenous infusion with caution if eGFR 30–80 mL/minute/1.73 m2; avoid intravenous infusion if eGFR less than 30 mL/minute/1.73 m2.

Contra indications

  • Acute porphyrias

Known side effects

General side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: Abdominal pain, diarrhoea, dyspnoea, headache, hepatitis, hypokalaemia, nausea, rash, taste disturbances, vomiting,

uncommon: Constipation, dizziness, dyspepsia, flatulence, menstrual disorder, myalgia, oedema, peripheral neuropathy (discontinue treatment),

rare: Alopecia, deafness, erectile dysfunction, heart failure, hypertriglyceridaemia, leucopenia, pancreatitis, photosensitivity, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, tinnitus, toxic epidermal necrolysis, urinary frequency, visual disturbances,

notKnown: Arthralgia, blood pressure changes, confusion, drowsiness, hepatotoxicity, renal impairment, thrombocytopenia, tremor,

Specific side effects

notKnown: hyperglycaemia,

Hepatotoxicity

Potentially life-threatening hepatotoxicity reported very rarely—discontinue if signs of hepatitis develop.

Directions for administration

With intravenous use

For intravenous infusion (Sporanox ), give intermittently in Sodium Chloride 0.9%; dilute 250 mg in 50 mL infusion fluid and infuse only 60 mL through an in-line filter (0.2 micron) over 60 minutes.

With oral use

For oral liquid, do not take with food; swish around mouth and swallow, do not rinse afterwards.

Advice for patients and carers

Patients should be told how to recognise signs of liver disorder and advised to seek prompt medical attention if symptoms such as anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fatigue, abdominal pain or dark urine develop.

With oral use

Patients or carers should be given advice on how to administer itraconazole oral liquid.

Important safety information

Heart failure

Following reports of heart failure, caution is advised when prescribing itraconazole to patients at high risk of heart failure. Those at risk include:

  • patients receiving high doses and longer treatment courses;
  • older adults and those with cardiac disease;
  • patients with chronic lung disease (including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) associated with pulmonary hypertension;
  • patients receiving treatment with negative inotropic drugs, e.g. calcium channel blockers.

Itraconazole should be avoided in patients with ventricular dysfunction or a history of heart failure unless the infection is serious.

Cautions regarding administration

  • Active liver disease
  • history of hepatotoxicity with other drugs
  • susceptibility to congestive heart failure

Advice regarding conception and contraception

Ensure effective contraception during treatment and until the next menstrual period following end of treatment.

Monitoring requirements

Therapeutic drug monitoring

Absorption reduced in AIDS and neutropenia (monitor plasma-itraconazole concentration and increase dose if necessary).

Patient parameters

Monitor liver function if treatment continues for longer than one month, if receiving other hepatotoxic drugs, if history of hepatotoxicity with other drugs, or in hepatic impairment.

Unlicensed use

Itraconazole doses in BNF may differ from those in product literature.

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

Flavours of oral liquid formulations may include cherry.

Prepared medicinal forms of ITRACONAZOLE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: oral solution, oral suspension,
